description: From Middle English mincen, minsen; partly from Old English minsian, Ä¡eminsian (â€œto make less, make smaller, diminishâ€), from Proto-West Germanic *minnisÅn, from Proto-Germanic *minnisÅnÄ… (â€œto make lessâ€); partly from Old French mincer, mincier (â€œto cut into small piecesâ€), from mince (â€œslender, slight, punyâ€), from Frankish *minsto, *minnisto, superlative of *min, *minn (â€œsmall, lessâ€), from Proto-Germanic *minniz (â€œlessâ€); both from Proto-Indo-European *mey- (â€œsmall, littleâ€). Cognate with Old Saxon minsÅn (â€œto make less, make smallerâ€), Old Dutch minson (â€œto make smallerâ€), Gothic ğŒ¼ğŒ¹ğŒ½ğŒ¶ğŒ½ğŒ°ğŒ½ (minznan, â€œto become less, diminishâ€), Swedish minska (â€œto reduce, lessenâ€), Gothic ğŒ¼ğŒ¹ğŒ½ğƒ (mins, â€œslender, slightâ€). More at min.

examples: Mince tastes really good fried in a pan with some chopped onion and tomato.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Finely chopped mixed fruit used in Christmas pies; mincemeat.
examples: During Christmas time my dad loves to eat mince pies.

entries.meaning: (countable) An affected (often dainty or short and precise) gait.
examples: His skin was china pale, he walked with a slight mince, and his silver mustache was always trimmed sharp; it was his custom to send a bouquet of pink carnations to the wives of men with whom he dined.

entries.meaning: (countable) An affected manner, especially of speaking; an affectation.
examples: And, further, who has not heard what someone has christened the "Oxford" mince, where every consonant is mispronounced and every vowel gets a wrong value?

entries.meaning: (countable, Cockney rhyming slang, chiefly in the plural) An eye (from mince pie).

verbs.description: mince (third-person singular simple present minces, present participle mincing, simple past and past participle minced)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make less; to make small.
(transitive) To lessen; to diminish; to diminish in speaking; to speak of lightly or slightingly; to minimise.
(transitive, cooking) To cut into very small pieces; to chop finely.
examples: Butchers often use machines to mince meat.

entries.meaning: (archaic, transitive, figuratively) To suppress or weaken the force of.
To say or utter vaguely (not directly or frankly).
(transitive) To affect; to pronounce affectedly or with an accent.
examples: In some districts of England ll is sounded like w, thus bowd (booud) for BOLD, bw (buu) for BULL, caw (kau) for CALL. But this pronunciation is merely a provincialism, and not to be imitated unless you wish to mince like these blunderers.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To walk with short steps; to walk in a prim, affected manner.
examples: At the last moment Mollie, the foolish, pretty white mare who drew Mr. Jones's trap, came mincing daintily in, chewing at a lump of sugar.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To act or talk with affected nicety; to affect delicacy in manner.
examples: I love going to gay bars and seeing drag queens mince around on stage.
